discussion.content: You mean, single point of contact? This must be typo..

choices.B: Designate a single port of contact and at least one backup for contact with the media.
choices.A: Allow any senior management level personnel with knowledge of the incident to discuss it.
choices.D: Release financial information on the impact of damages caused by the incident.
choices.C: Stipulate that incidents are not to be discussed with the media at any time during the incident.

questions.question_text: Which of the allowing is a best practice with regard to interacting with the media during an incident?

discussion.content: By whitelisting the few key vendors that actually need access to the website, the DDOS attack will stop because they wouldn't have access anymore.

“For a few key vendors”
Whitelist them which would block everything else
A honeyspot is used to detect attackers, it has nothing to do with keeping a website online.

comments.content: Honeypot doesn't improve availability of the site. Whitelisting will allow authorised vendors and drop unauthorised source IPs

questions.question_text: A company has recently launched a new billing invoice website for a few key vendors. The cybersecurity analyst is receiving calls that the website is performing slowly and the pages sometimes time out. The analyst notices the website is receiving millions of requests, causing the service to become unavailable. Which of the following can be implemented to maintain the availability of the website?

Several accounting department users are reporting unusual Internet traffic in the browsing history of their workstations after returning to work and logging in. The building security team informs the IT security team that the cleaning staff was caught using the systems after the accounting department users left for the day.
Which of the following steps should the IT security team take to help prevent this from happening again? (Choose two.)

choices.E: Set up a camera to monitor the workstations for unauthorized use.
choices.A: Install a web monitor application to track Internet usage after hours.
choices.D: Configure mandatory access controls to allow only accounting department users to access the workstations.
choices.C: Configure NAC to set time-based restrictions on the accounting group to normal business hours.
choices.B: Configure a policy for workstation account timeout at three minutes.

discussion.content: Although extreme, it’s b and c. A and E would not prevent it’s only get evidence. D does not work because they already have access to accounting workstations, this rule might already be in affect.

C and D. Only a fool will choose B.

Account is already been compromised so its not B. both C and D is a preventive controls so its not E.

Yeah, maybe a bit extreme though. They'll get users complaining that their workstation locks out very fast, but i think it'll prevent the cleaning staff from using his machine, unless he is ready to take over by the minute the accounting staff leaves his desk lol
I fill like 3 minutes is a bit extreme. Would MAC be a better choice?

comments.content: Mandatory Access Control seems like a mistake tbh. If this were Rule Based Access Control then sure. MAC is more for files I believe.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
The first 12 bytes represent the destination MAC address, source MAC address, and EtherType.
The next 20 bytes represent the IP header with source and destination IP addresses and protocol type (UDP).
The next 12 bytes represent the UDP header with source and destination ports.

50 18 fb 90 - The next 4 bytes represent the DNS header, where "50 18" represents the DNS identification number, and "fb 90" represents the flags.
The next 10 bytes represent the DNS question section.
The next 2 bytes represent the DNS answer section.
The next 4 bytes represent the DNS name server records section.
The next 17 bytes represent the DNS additional records section.
The last 3 bytes represent the DNS additional records section.

Therefore, the packet is a DNS over UDP standard query that requests the IP address of "comp.tia" with identification number "50 18".

"when you see this displayed in Wireshark – all the ……… in between the letters and other words – tells you that it is an ISC BIND PATCH — the only answer for DNS BIND is listed above…"

Source: https://vceguide.com/which-of-the-following-best-describes-this-packet/

comments.content: What was your choice? I am torn between A and D
You will get the ............ in the standard query as well

discussion.content: Can anyone shed some light on this? This looks like an UDP standard query to me... .

choices.C: DNS over TCP server status query

questions.question_text:
A security analyst is reviewing packet captures to determine the extent of success during an attacker's reconnaissance phase following a recent incident.
The following is a hex and ASCII dump of one such packet:
//IMG//

Which of the following BEST describes this packet?

discussion.content:
Port 80 doesn't reply to Xmas scan, So it's open
However ports 22 and 445 replies with RST which means they are closed.
It should be B.
https://nmap.org/book/scan-methods-null-fin-xmas-scan.html#scan-methods-tbl-nullfinxmas-scan-responses
No, it's a file server, as it's got ssh running (often used for transferring files) and SMB (port 445) running, also used for files

comments.content: No, it's not. The log shows nmap probing 192.168.1.55 for ports 22, 80, and 445. Line 48 and 49 shows that port 22 and 445 replied with a RST, ACK packet meaning that these two ports are closed. Line 50 shows that port 80 is open. Only port 80 is open the server, therefore answer is B.

you're looking on a wrong IP
This is a file server as all 3 ports are open. Look at the lines 45,46,47

discussion.content: This should be B, port 80 is open per logs.
I'm not sure how this is a file server. It should be a web server
